adventure-vision-story.text: The Challenge Awaits. You've learned variables, loops, conditions, and functions. Now it's time for the ultimate test—building a complete text adventure game from scratch!
What is a Text Adventure?. A text adventure is a game where players type commands to explore, collect items, and reach goals. No fancy graphics needed—just your imagination and code!
The Player Experience. Players wake up in a dungeon. They type 'pick up key' and 'go north' to explore. The game responds to their commands, creating an interactive story they control.

Everything Comes Together. This project combines every skill you've learned: Stone for memory, Lightning for decisions, Magnetism for functions, and Architect thinking for planning. It all clicks into place!
The Victory Moment. When a player escapes the castle and sees 'Congratulations! You escaped!'—that's YOUR code creating that magic moment. You built something real and playable!

game-planning-story.text: Architects Plan First. Great game developers don't just start typing code. Like architects designing a building, they draw a plan first. Your map IS your blueprint!
Draw Your Map. Sketch out your rooms and how they connect. Dungeon leads north to the Hall. Hall connects to Kitchen, Library, and Tower. Each arrow is a path players can walk.
Define Your Rooms. Every room needs three things: a description that sets the mood, exits telling where players can go, and items they might find. That's the recipe for a room!
Add Items to Collect. Rusty key in the dungeon. Apple in the kitchen. Magic scroll in the library. Items make exploration rewarding and can unlock new paths through your adventure.
Set the Win Condition. Every game needs a goal! Reach the tower to escape, collect all treasures, defeat the dragon—you decide. The win condition gives players something to strive for.

skills-integration-story.text: Stone: Your Data Foundation. Remember the Stone? Variables store everything your helper needs—the joke list, the fact database, the to-do list. Data is the foundation your AI helper is built on!
Stone: Game Memory. Variables store everything: current room tracks where the player is, inventory holds collected items, and game running controls if the loop continues. The Stone remembers!

Magnetism: Reusable Functions. Each feature is a function! tell_joke, do_math, show_todos—they're all Magnetism at work. You write the logic once, then call it whenever needed. Functions make your code clean and powerful!

Architect: The Big Picture. The Architect mindset ties it all together. You designed a system where input flows to parsing, parsing routes to features, and features return responses. That's architecture!

The Complete Picture. Your AI helper uses ALL of these skills together! Stone stores data, Lightning makes decisions, Magnetism organizes code into functions, and the Architect designs the flow. You've become a real programmer!
Your Complete Game. Stone holds the state, Lightning makes decisions, Magnetism provides the actions, and the game loop ties it all together. You're not just coding—you're creating an experience!

adventure-vision-story.text: The Challenge Awaits. You've learned variables, loops, conditions, and functions. Now it's time for the ultimate test—building a complete text adventure game from scratch!
What is a Text Adventure?. A text adventure is a game where players type commands to explore, collect items, and reach goals. No fancy graphics needed—just your imagination and code!
The Player Experience. Players wake up in a dungeon. They type 'pick up key' and 'go north' to explore. The game responds to their commands, creating an interactive story they control.

Everything Comes Together. This project combines every skill you've learned: Stone for memory, Lightning for decisions, Magnetism for functions, and Architect thinking for planning. It all clicks into place!
The Victory Moment. When a player escapes the castle and sees 'Congratulations! You escaped!'—that's YOUR code creating that magic moment. You built something real and playable!

game-planning-story.text: Architects Plan First. Great game developers don't just start typing code. Like architects designing a building, they draw a plan first. Your map IS your blueprint!
Draw Your Map. Sketch out your rooms and how they connect. Dungeon leads north to the Hall. Hall connects to Kitchen, Library, and Tower. Each arrow is a path players can walk.
Define Your Rooms. Every room needs three things: a description that sets the mood, exits telling where players can go, and items they might find. That's the recipe for a room!
Add Items to Collect. Rusty key in the dungeon. Apple in the kitchen. Magic scroll in the library. Items make exploration rewarding and can unlock new paths through your adventure.
Set the Win Condition. Every game needs a goal! Reach the tower to escape, collect all treasures, defeat the dragon—you decide. The win condition gives players something to strive for.

skills-integration-story.text: Stone: Your Data Foundation. Remember the Stone? Variables store everything your helper needs—the joke list, the fact database, the to-do list. Data is the foundation your AI helper is built on!

Lightning: Making Decisions. Lightning taught you if-elif-else. That's exactly how your helper decides what to do! If the user says 'joke', do this. Elif they say 'time', do that. Decisions power the routing!

Magnetism: Reusable Functions. Each feature is a function! tell_joke, do_math, show_todos—they're all Magnetism at work. You write the logic once, then call it whenever needed. Functions make your code clean and powerful!

Architect: The Big Picture. The Architect mindset ties it all together. You designed a system where input flows to parsing, parsing routes to features, and features return responses. That's architecture!
The Game Loop. While game running: show the room, get a command, decide what to do, call the right function, check for victory, repeat. That's the heartbeat of your adventure game!
Your Complete Game. Stone holds the state, Lightning makes decisions, Magnetism provides the actions, and the game loop ties it all together. You're not just coding—you're creating an experience!
